content.text: * Title: Probability and Statistics Code: TOKT1145
* Credits: three-credit course (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
Address: Suite 1108, Building A1, National Economics University
1. Bui Duong Hai, MSc Tel: Email: haibd@neu.edu.vn
2. Nguyen Hai Duong, MSc Tel: Email: duong79tkt@neu.edu.vn
3. Vu Thi Bich Ngọc, MSc Tel: Email: ngocvu@neu.edu.vn
4. Nguyen Thi Thuy Trang, MSc Tel: Email: thuytrang@neu.edu.vn
5. Mai Cam Tu, MSc Tel: Email: tumc@neu.edu.vn
* Office hours: Monday-Thursday, 10:00-11:00 am, or by appointment

This course is a study of quantitative methods used in data analysis and economic-business decision making, including descriptive statistics and inferential statistics. The course provides students theory and appropriate techniques of interpreting, analyzing, deducing information from data. Topics include the role of statistics in modern business environments and for management information, data collection, data tabulation, probability concepts and probability distributions, sampling distribution, interval estimation, hypothesis testing and regression.
[1] Main text: Anderson, Sweeney, Williams, Camm, Cochran (2017), Statistics for Business and Economics, 12th Edition, South-Western, chapter 1 to 11 and 14 to 16.
[2] Paul Newbold, William L. Carlson, Betty Thorne (2013), Statistics for Business and Economics, 8th Edition, Pearson, chapter 1 to 12.
[3] Additional: Linda H., John F. (2013). Applied Statistics for Business and Management using Microsoft Excel, Springer.
[4] Additional: Verma J. P. (2013). Data Analysis in Management with SPSS Software, Springer.
a. Microsoft Excel with Data Analysis Toolpak
b. SPSS software, STATA, R, Python

cells: Understand the role and significant of statistics in economics and business; Present data in convenient and informative way, interpret and analyze graph, numerical statistics, using software and presentation tools; Understand concepts and application of probability, probability distribution; Apply inferential statistics in economics and business decision making; Using linear regression and correlation to analyze relationship of economic and business variables.

column_map.Goal Description: Understand the role and significant of statistics in economics and business; Present data in convenient and informative way, interpret and analyze graph, numerical statistics, using software and presentation tools; Understand concepts and application of probability, probability distribution; Apply inferential statistics in economics and business decision making; Using linear regression and correlation to analyze relationship of economic and business variables.

Solve previous home work Lecture Discussion Excel practice

column_map.Activities: Solve previous home work Lecture Discussion Excel practice

Solve previous home work Lecture Discussion Excel practice

column_map.Content: Lecture 11. Testing for Two parameters 11.1. Dependent and Independent samples - Pair samples - Independent samples 11.2. Test for two means - Formula - Application 11.3. Test for two variances - Formula - Application 11.4. Test for two proportions - Formula - Application
column_map.Activities: Solve previous home work Lecture Discussion Excel practice

cells: Revision - Summary content of the course - Revision of final exam

column_map.Content: Revision - Summary content of the course - Revision of final exam

content.text: Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).

Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments, these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

full_text:
* Title: Probability and Statistics Code: TOKT1145
* Credits: three-credit course (45 credit hours; 1 credit hour = 50 minutes of lecture)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 30 hrs
+ Exercise and discussion: 15 hrs
+ Self-study: 90 hrs.
* Parallel course(s): None.
* Prerequisite course(s): None
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Mathematical Economics
Address: Suite 1108, Building A1, National Economics University
Tel: 024 36 280280 Ext: 6146
+ Department: Mathematical Economics
+ Lecturers:
1. Bui Duong Hai, MSc Tel: Email: haibd@neu.edu.vn
2. Nguyen Hai Duong, MSc Tel: Email: duong79tkt@neu.edu.vn
3. Vu Thi Bich Ngọc, MSc Tel: Email: ngocvu@neu.edu.vn
4. Nguyen Thi Thuy Trang, MSc Tel: Email: thuytrang@neu.edu.vn
5. Mai Cam Tu, MSc Tel: Email: tumc@neu.edu.vn
* Kind of course:
* Course language: In English
* Office hours: Monday-Thursday, 10:00-11:00 am, or by appointment
This course is a study of quantitative methods used in data analysis and economic-business decision making, including descriptive statistics and inferential statistics. The course provides students theory and appropriate techniques of interpreting, analyzing, deducing information from data. Topics include the role of statistics in modern business environments and for management information, data collection, data tabulation, probability concepts and probability distributions, sampling distribution, interval estimation, hypothesis testing and regression.
* Textbooks/Lecture Notes:
[1] Main text: Anderson, Sweeney, Williams, Camm, Cochran (2017), Statistics for Business and Economics, 12th Edition, South-Western, chapter 1 to 11 and 14 to 16.
[2] Paul Newbold, William L. Carlson, Betty Thorne (2013), Statistics for Business and Economics, 8th Edition, Pearson, chapter 1 to 12.
[3] Additional: Linda H., John F. (2013). Applied Statistics for Business and Management using Microsoft Excel, Springer.
[4] Additional: Verma J. P. (2013). Data Analysis in Management with SPSS Software, Springer.
Other requirement materials & Information
a. Microsoft Excel with Data Analysis Toolpak
b. SPSS software, STATA, R, Python
c. Excel Guidebook, NEU
d. Data by the teachers

Table 8.1. Lesson plan for the course
Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments, these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
